threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

last_replies.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

threads.com:
Show us your failures edition
Last Thread: >>2501956

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

>I'm new to electronics. Where to get started?
It is an art/science of applying principles to requirements.
Find problem, learn principles, design and verify solution, build, test, post results, repeat.

>Incredibly comprehensive list of electronics resources:
https://github.com/kitspace/awesome-electronics
Additional resources below:

>Project ideas:
https://adafruit.com
https://instructables.com/tag/type-id/category-technology/
https://makezine.com/category/electronics/
https://hackaday.io

>Don't ask, roll:
https://github.com/Rocheez/4chan-electronics-challenges/blob/master/list-of-challenges.png

>Archive of Popular Electronics magazines (1954-2003):
https://worldradiohistory.com/Popular-Electronics-Guide.htm
>Microchip Tips and Tricks PDF:
https://ww1.microchip.com/downloads/en/devicedoc/01146b.pdf
>Li+/LiPo batteries required reading:
https://www.elteconline.com/download/pdf/SAFT-RIC-LI-ION-Safety-Recommendations.pdf

Mims III, Getting Started in Electronics
Geier, How to Diagnose & Fix Everything Electronic
Kybett & Boysen, All New Electronics Self-Teaching Guide
Scherz & Monk, Practical Electronics for Inventors (arguably has minor issues with mains grounding)

eBay/AliExpress sellers, for component assortments/sample kits (caveat emptor)

>>2509382
see pic rel for basic idea that applies to all pieces I made. I dunno how you would print that. Gonna paste my an explanation

It consists of a backer plate (9 light + 9 heavy layers), porcelain shards and a topper (3 +3) encasing the ceramics. Wanted to use 2 offset layers of ceramics, instead I placed the first and additional shards on what I deemed crucial parts of the armor.

This is the basic method for all armor parts I made, a full plate with porcelain for my mask, forearms and torso, the rest consists only of the backer type plate, 18 layers of sandwiched light and heavy glass cloth.

Made a visor from 1cm thick polycarbonat. Went trough some trial and error while attempting to heat bend it. Made a bubble free curved piece with our oven, the trick is to heat it up to 150c first and frequently open the door to let out steam, after a while turn it up to 175c. I want to thank thermoplastic anon for that info again. Another thanks to soap bar anon, scrub a bar of soap then wipe with a dry towel on glassy surfaces like glasses you don't want to fog up with your breath, it really works.

>specialize
>all kinds of materials
>different applications
There are companies that specialize in drilling, but they are truly specialized, like well drillers.
Microdrilling is very specialized, so much that companies may only deal in one or two types of material.
Companies like that may take in and process parts for other manufacturers and only do holes, but for fabrication purposes you have to consider that there's many other ways of making holes that are often faster, safer, less wasteful, more accurate, etc. so most things that need lots of holes are designed to avoid drilling them and cast or forge or mold or 3D print them into parts from the get-go, punch them, broach them. water jet and laser/plasma/edm cut them, etc.
Rotary drilling is better suited to the kinds of jobs that don't provide enough work to support an entire company, unless it's very skill/tech equipment dependent and highly specified

This is not about cultural notions of good or bad or subjectivity or quality, it is about anon getting disappointed and giving up because he spent a huge amount of time making an instrument that is completely incapable of playing the music he wants to play. You might as well just tell him to pick up the kazoo and convince himself it is the greatest sounding koto ever.

Beyond that, the bridges in this family of instrument are movable and moving them is part of how you tune them. Flat topped instruments require their bracing to be designed around the bridge placement and the braces create live and dead spots on the soundboard and areas with very different tonality, the string will drastically change sound and volume when its bridge is moved to setup for different pieces. Now you could design a bracing pattern which would work if you know what you are doing, but anon does not know what he is doing, you probably could just get away with a lattice bracing and have ok results but making that lattice will be a great deal of work, possibly more work than carving in the end.

And that does not even take into consideration of the physical, the pressure applied by the bridges of a koto and the eastern zithers are about as irritating as you could get for a flat top instrument, almost the entire length of the soundboard needs to be able to standup to the pressure of a bridge and be reasonably acoustically active. This is not so easy to accomplish with a flat top.

>>2508845
A spoke shave like the Miller Falls #1 would probably be very handy and much quicker than files. A cheaper flat soled spoke shave would also not be bad to have but not quite as useful for your work. threads.com: I always assumed that a tiny voltage would have trouble moving through a huge wire. That's why we use small wires for low voltage, right? Yet science tells me that in fact smaller wires have higher resistance so the voltage would actually travel though bigger wire better. Is this true? Would 1v travel better though a huge thick mains voltage cable than a small speaker wire??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508479
>Too hard to manufacture for the price of making a solid wire of similar ampacity

Go look at the price of a 1" copper plumbing pipe. Then go look at the price of a solid 1" bar of copper. The price difference is huge, and plumbing pipe is DOM tube (a notably more expensive process than welded). Additionally, the exact thing being described already exists and is widespread in the form of braided shielding.

The logic of "hurr durr all that matters is outer diameter" is retarded on its face. Otherwise, you could do shit like run 100A through RG6 no problem. Go try it, tell me how well that goes.

>That's called copper clad wire and its use in industry is well established.

Yeah, and it's used mostly because aluminum is cheaper for a given ampacity than copper. The only reason it's coated in copper is because copper/aluminum junctions are a nightmare scenario for promoting galvanic corrosion. Having aluminum in direct contact with copper will quickly destroy the connection, possibly within mere days if it gets wet with something like salt water. It's also seen where large conductor needs to span a significant length and the weight/strength of copper would be a problem, but bare aluminum wire won't do (again, usually for corrosion/weathering reasons).

Go look at literally any of the NEC charts dictating the maximum amp rating for copper wire and CCA wire of the same gauge. They're not even close. You know why? Because the whole wire is conducting, not just the outer surface.

Yeah, I think I've already done more than enough by going with 10AWG instead of 12, making sure the nickel strips I ordered are pure nickel and going with XT90S connectors (maybe you're going to say that crimped Andersons or whatnot are better but idk, that anti spark function sounds great, but I could always change later if I want).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508948
>XT90S connector

The only issue is that they use solder cups. Soldered connections effectively solidify a wire at the joint and negate the benefits of high-strand wires. You can mostly counteract the issue by securing the wires/connector as solidly as possible near the joint. It doesn't really matter if the connections are more brittle if they're prevented from moving in the first place.

Inside, when I turn on the oven, it clicks and lights the pilot. The pilot flame comes on after a concerningly long amount of clicking (which I attribute to mice chewing on the wires to the spark), but the rest of the pipe never lights. It is equipped with a mercury capillary-driven safety valve with a bulb over the pilot light, so if the pilot goes out the gas will stop. I have confirmed the safety valve works by removing it, holding a lighter to the bulb, and blowing through where the propane goes. After about 10 seconds of heat on the bulb I can feel it suddenly open up and air comes out where it's meant to. The main pipe the oven flames are supposed to come from is not clogged, it's not even dirty.
It does have a regulator on the back, which I have never touched. I've read online that in many cases the regulator is just for the oven part and if it fails the stovetop will still work. What do you guys like for modern production environment design?

I found this firm in my country that uses stainless tubes to configure all sorts of tables, carts etc. Also there's MayTec and Bosch/Rexroth that use mostly extruded aluminium profiles, these two also have their own CAD software to allow quick configuration of all sorts of setups, which is nice.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I work at a Toyota subsidiary, and we use Toyota Production System (many influences on modern lean ideas). I'm in the US.
We use a huge amount of the pipe & joint stuff. The same kind of thing you reference as "stainless tubes". Vendor lock-in is the unfortunate reality. For the first few years we sourced stuff from Creform, then switched to PAC. That second compnay does not show up readily in search results unless you search the full name 'Production Automation Corporation'. Same size parts are generally interchangeable, but the fit is off--like putting together LEGO and MegaBloks.

One advantage for this kind of system is that reworking a station, cart, bench, etc takes one day, or an off-shift. It's easy and fast enough that you can iterate on designs. Just keep a cabinet with the most common parts, some extra tubes, etc. A big benefit for me is that the workers/users can do simple repairs/mods. If something is loose, or misaligned, or needs moved 1" to the left, they can do it with a set of hex keys. If you know someone isn't a retard, you can also give them a tubing cutter & deburr tool--lete them do the work vs trying to explain it.

Last, I'll mention that we did some test setups with 80 20 aluminum extrusion. One guy had a hardon for it. I'm pretty sure it's on the "We tried it, and it doesn't hold up the like steel tubes do" list forever.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508841
I'm talking about startup current. It's not like it never works, but you're exceeding the ratings the device was designed for. A 5000W induction motor would extremely likely blow these 5000W inverters immediately, because a 5000W induction motor can temporarily draw 20-25kW on startup. Ideally you should be using a low frequency inverter. A small split AC can work on the 5000W Bluetti because they have 10kW surge, so in that regard you're just overpaying compared to the $600 solar inverter that can do the same. As a rule of thumb for induction devices, you need to oversize the HF inverter's peak load by a factor of 7.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2506471
>How efficient would a wind up battery be?
well, we can look at volumetric energy storage in (J/cubic meter) and total possible energy in (J):
total energy:
stored_energy=1/2∗k∗(θ)^2
where :
k is the spring constant
θ the final angle in (rad)

finding the efficiency volumetrically is a bit more difficult and more material dependent but I will try to compare it with something we are familiar with like energy stored in elevated mass, so lets use a 1kg block of ASTM A229 spring steal and the same mass for the spring; starting for the elevated mass:
total energy=mgh ; if we assume height to be 1m
(1kg)(9.8m/s2)(1m)=9.8J
for volumetric energy storage, 76.44 J/cubic meter.

the spring :
total energy=1/2∗k∗(θ)^2;
Rate per degree : 0.137 N-mm/Degree
Spring Rate (or Spring constant) per 360 degrees, k360 degrees: 49.195 N-mm/360 Degrees
Maximum torque possible, Torquemax : 6,159.806 N-mm
Safe Travel
Maximum safe travel, Travelmax : 45,075.9299 Degrees
Physical Dimensions
Diameter of spring wire, d: 2.250 mm
Outer diameter of spring, Douter : 1,000.000 mm
Inner diameter of spring, Dinner : 995.500 mm
Mean diameter of spring, Dmean : 997.750 mm
Number of active coils, na : 10.000
Body length, Lbody : 24.750 mm
Length of leg 1: 10.000 mm
Length of leg 2: 10.000 mm
Total leg length: 20.000 mm
Direction of wind : Left hand
Spring index, C : 443.444
(0.5)(7.8 N-mm/rad)(7907.7rad)^2=243.9MJ
and for volumetric energy storage is 69GJ/cubic meter which is huge like 7 billion to 1.
>Could wind up batteries be used as ecologically safe batteries for electricity gained from renewable resources?
perhaps, but it is highly unlikely due to their "charging" behavior, the more u wind the spring the greater the energy required to turn it exponentially according to the equation:
total energy=1/2∗k∗(θ)^2;
which is the reason why it has such a high volumetric energy storage compared to gravity for the same material an mass.

What i've discovered after having some heavy rain on a recently erected prefab:
>tannalised / pressure treated wood is a must
>avoid shitlap and go for tongue and groove
>be generous with weather resistant paint
>fill any huge interior gaps with weather resistant expanding foam and trim as needed
>fill any joints between panels and exterior gaps with weather resistant sillicone sealant or similar
>install regular house size guttering
>have good concrete paving foundation raised above ground level by an inch or two
>ensure that any hard ground / exposed foundation around the edges of the shed has either guttering above or somehting to deflect rainwater splashback away from the wood
>allow an inch or so in between the foundations and the floor of the shed for ventilation

last_replies.com:
https://ww w.finewoodworking. com/2008/03/21/a-benchtop-bench

Synopsis: Woodworking benches are designed to place the workpiece at a height that’s ideal for handplaning. But that height is often too low for routing and handwork. Furniture maker Jeff Miller built a mini-bench that elevates workpieces to a more comfortable height.

Extraction woodworking benches are designed to place a workpiece at a height that’s ideal for handplaning. But the perfect height for planing often is too low for other common bench tasks. For example, when routing, carving, cutting dovetails, or doing layout, I frequently have found myself bent over at an uncomfortable angle so that I could see clearly and work effectively. When performing these tasks, I like to have a workpiece positioned 6 in. to 10 in. above my waist level.

To bring a workpiece to my ideal height range, I made a small workbench that mounts quickly to my regular bench. When extra height is needed, the minibench effectively raises the work-surface to my comfort zone. The bench is easy to move, stores nicely under my bigger bench, and includes a vise that provides plenty of holding force.

Nothing I'd call a "problem" that was specific to that product or its mechanism, like any toilet sometimes it needs extra attention to get the bowl clean of stuck on poop, and that cuts into the holding tank capacity if you rely on the built in flush water thing to sluice it out. We just kept a spray bottle with a stream nozzle next to it, and did the pre-lining with TP to minimize that.

The knife type valve that closes off the holding tank from the bowl needs to be kept free of mineral deposits so the rubber seal doesn't get damaged and leak but even with full time use that just meant using some vinegar or CLR every 6-8 months or so and maybe some gentle scraping with a plastic scraper.
Never had a leak in use or when carrying it upright where that valve is keeping the sewage in, or with the swiveling pour spout and cap.
We definitely babied it for fear of breaking something and having a mess, but it worked great. One thing we did was build a small base to bring it up to a taller height to minimize the inertia of someone sitting on it that might stress it enough to break something.

What you're doing is essentially what my father did growing up. All forms of throwing your compostable stuff to the ground and letting it rot and dissolve into the earth is ok, but if you want to have a super-rich soil load every year, composting it in place is best. Turning it over is necessary and if you want to avoid concentrations of certain bacteria, you want to avoid tossing in fats and citrus and a few other things.

Sometimes doing the bare minimum is effective, but not the most beneficial.

Arduino
>The system should turn on after pressing S1 S2 and S3 sequentially
Use a variable for a flag. Set it to 0

Then use a loop that runs until the flag=3{
If s1 is pressed, set the flag to 1
If s2 is pressed set the flag to 2 if it's currently 1, otherwise set it back to 0
If s3 is pressed set the flag to 3 if it's currently 2, otherwise set it back to 0
}

>light sequence
Use an infinite loop{
Turn on green light
wait 10 sec
Turn off green and turn on orange
wait 2 sec
... continue for full sequence
}

Look up how to blink an LED with an arduino, then look up how to poll buttons

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: I would put it in a box and pour some sort of liquid rubber around it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505931
That and for handling OP could fab a simple cart (because bending over is bad) to hold the mould in a removable tray. If you're going to do something many times it's wise to make it easy.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505917
What would be best depends on how many you need to make, also you don't show the edge detail on the far side...but assuming it's a typical pool coping tile with a square edge there I would cast a plaster mold oriented like picrel where that RH piece is flat stock (could be wood or metal) that comes off and you tilt the finished casting up and out. You could probably count on shrinkage (and an accurate plug) and liberal mold release to make the sides pop loose and keep it to two parts, or make the sides separate and strap it all together with a ratchet strap before pouring.
Rubber would work too but isn't necessary for that little detail and breaks down faster.
Just wax the hell out of the plaster so its sealed, apply a mold release over that when it's assembled, and you're good to go.
Also fwiw for that kind of part you can also make an extra long mold of that profile and have fitted plugs to dam off the ends at different lengths for longer/shorter/multiple tiles, to make miters, interlocking ends, etc.

threads.com: What's /diy/s opinion of cob? Finding tons of absolutely beautiful builds online and I've always been enamoured with earthships and undergrounds/hobbit holes. Would it be worth it or does the material suck? Even if I just make a studio it doesn't look like it would take much to just add on to it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502905
It's incredibly cheap to build and also very DIY friendly.

The biggest problem with it is that it's very time consuming. Each layer has to set and you've got to allow for shrinkage.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502388
>Would it be worth it or does the material suck?
theres nothing really wrong with it although it has advantages and disadvantages versus other materials for any given application.
IMO the main problem with cob is the immense amount of physical labor to get it done.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502388
Depends on the climate and environment. If your country or county is rich in cob, it's a cheap material and depending on the way it's built, it can be easier to build alone than laying bricks. The best climate is if you live in a normal or dryer climate.
As methods, you can look up example traditional hungarian cob houses. They used (sometimes not) woven net as basic wall structure, and layer by layer plastered cob on it. They made half meter thickness usually. The positive side to it that summer was always cool inside and the air quality is top notch, never dry, and with the good lime plaster it never gets wet. Bad side is that they had to make huge roof over hanger to avoid wetness from rain. They painted the wall yearly again as protection.
An other, more geometrical method: Look up japanese cob wall installations. They build it wall by wall or panel by panel where they use a wire mesh so it holds the cob and gives more flexibility to the walls, but the weight holding structure is wood there.

For someone who is looking to get into leatherworking, what thickness of leather would you recommend purchasing? I'm thinking of starting out with 2-3oz veg tan leather because I feel like it will probably be easiest to work with as a newbie. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507045
Veg tan is the way to go, thickness depends entirely on what you are making. You're not going to make a good wallet out of the thick stuff, and you can't make a good belt out of the thin stuff.

I don't think it matters in the long run what thickness you learn on. If you stick with the hobby for more than a couple projects, you'll just end up getting another kind of leather anyway.

I do recommend getting a whole hide (or a side) if you plan on doing belts. Cows seem real big until you try and find 40 continuous inches in a straight line.

this would be an idea. print it mirror-inverted.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2506928
The main thing here is the ink, you will be gluing the ink down which is between the transparency and the acrylic, so you want something that bonds well. I would go with a laser printer over an inkjet. But inkjet may be just fine, cheap enough of an experiment, you can just print out some tests at any copy shop for a $1 and see if there is peeling problems if you do not have access to both types of printers.

I would talk to a sign shop, they have more durable methods and better films/glues. The signs they make mean to be stuck on windows without obscuring much of the view are pretty much ready made and will come with the adhesive applied, just peel the backing and stick it on the acrylic. They may also have some other options, talk to them, see what they suggest. Many of these can be quite affordable since all they need to do is print them and there is no real labor.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505003
That's a reasonable approach and while the 12/12 thing is kind of arbitrary and perhaps not optimal, learning why and what might work better *for you* is valuable in and of itself, and probably won't take a full year and hindsight to be revealed.
Otherwise as long as you are realistic in your expectations there's nothing wrong with this approach and plenty of professional skills are taught in 4 week courses (or less) that are adequate for the academic portion of becoming certified. You have to be really focused to do it that way, but the point is that there's all kinds of skills that can be picked up in a short time and then built upon further if you want to master them.
You can learn to scuba dive and get certified in under a week and there are accelerated flight training schools where people get a pilots license in 2- weeks...it's not easy but it's possible so don't listen to people whose first response is to discourage you from your plan.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Cooking is probably the most useful skill to start with. You won't become a master in a month, but that's okay because you will probably practice it every day for the rest of your life. Don't forget to check if your kitchen fire extinguisher is good.
Then based on your limits, maybe a 3d printer. You will be able to learn about materials, design, and modeling.
Hand sewing can be useful to repair small tears and also save someones life in an emergency. A bit of thread and a needle is cheap too.
Actually go take a first aid course or get CPR certified while were on the subject, and put this near the top of your list just in case.
If you can't swim, find swimming lessons. Your skills won't do you good if you randomly drown.
